metadata.title: Pelvic Pain, Chronic, in Women
anatomical location body part affected: Pelvis, pelvic ligaments, pubic symphysis, sacroiliac (SI) joints, uterus, vagina, urological system, pelvic floor muscles (PFM), lower abdomen below the umbilicus, lumbar spine
description: Continuous or episodic pelvic pain that lasts for at least 6 months, occurs below the umbilicus, and is severe enough to interrupt normal ADLs, requiring medical or surgical treatment(20)
Chronic pelvic pain, by definition, is not caused by menstruation(1)

ICD-10 codes.N94.9: unspecified condition associated with female genital organs and menstrual cycle
ICD-10 codes.R10.2: pelvic and perineal pain (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Chronic pelvic pain is not a disease, but rather a condition associated with dysfunction in usually more than one of the following systems: gynecological, urological, gastrointestinal, musculoskeletal, and neurological

Signs and symptoms –Intermittent or constant pain, pressure, or heaviness deep within the pelvis –Dull aching –Cramping –Dyspareunia (pain with [or following] sexual intercourse) –Pain with defecation –Pain with urination –Pain with sitting down –Low back pain

Please see Clinical Review…Pelvic Girdle Pain: An Overview ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: 5000008059 for more information on this condition (e.g., symptoms, causes, precautions/contraindications, tests, treatment)

Please see Clinical Review…Pelvic Pain in Pregnancy ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: 5000007837 for more information on this condition (e.g., symptoms, causes, precautions/contraindications, tests, treatment)
Please see Clinical Review…Fracture, Pelvic ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: 5000007562 for more information on this condition (e.g., symptoms, causes, precautions/ contraindications, tests, treatment)

Please see Clinical Review…Sacroiliac Joint Dysfunction ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: 5000007883 for more information on this condition (e.g., symptoms, causes, precautions/contraindications, tests, treatment)

Please see Clinical Review…Symphysis Pubis Separation ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: 5000007887 for more information on this condition (e.g., symptoms, causes, precautions/contraindications, tests, treatment) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Only clinicians specifically trained in the evaluation/treatment of the pelvic floor should carry out portions of the examination related to this region
Maneuvers that duplicate the patient’s pain should be noted, but undue reproduction of pain should be avoided to minimize guarding, which can interfere with performance of a thorough exam

causes: Neuromuscular/musculoskeletal-related  causes can be the primary or secondary source of pain(9)

Gynecological-related  causes: pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), pelvic adhesions, endometriosis, pelvic relaxation,vaginal apex pain, ovarian remnant, pelvic congestion, dysmenorrhea, adenomyosis, chronic ectopic pregnancy, ovariancystic growth or bleeding, leiomyoma (uncommon), torsion of mass or organ, retrodisplaced uterus (rare)(9)–Current research suggests a weak correlation between pelvic adhesions and chronic pelvic pain(9)–Authors of a 2018 study conducted in the United Kingdom concluded that there was little to no correlation betweenpatient-reported  pain and pelvic adhesions identified with investigative laparoscopy. On the contrary, women with themost adhesions were found to have the lowest pain scores(18)
Many women with chronic pelvic pain have more than one condition that may lead to pain(1)
pathogenesis: Pathogenesis remains unclear and poorly understood. Chronic pelvic pain is a multisystem disorder that affects the mindand the body. It is thought to be a dynamic interaction between the brain and the musculoskeletal and organ systems(1)

Central sensitization–Researchers in Brazil found that sensitivity to experimental pain (electric stimulation was used) was reduced after6 months of multidisciplinary treatment for chronic pelvic pain, which provides additional evidence for centralsensitization(11)-Fifty-eight  patients participated in the study-Clinical management varied according to causal diagnosis (e.g., patients with musculoskeletal pain were treated withphysiotherapy; patients with endometriosis were treated with laparoscopic excision of lesions followed by hormonaltreatment; patients with gastroenterological symptoms were treated with dietary modification). Pain medications wereused to relieve symptoms during exacerbations-The results demonstrated a reduction of pain intensity perceived by the patient with treatment that was associated with aproportional increase in pain threshold

The gate control theory(1)–Pain impulses are regulated by the spinal cord, which serves as a “gate,” either allowing the impulse to reach the brain orstopping it before it reaches the brain–When the “gates” are negatively impacted through chronic pain, pain impulses may still travel to the brain even when theinitial root of the pain has been properly addressed
Neuropathic pain can develop from within nerves
risk factors: Risk factors for chronic pelvic pain; based on a systematic review(2)–Drug or alcohol abuse–Miscarriage–Heavy menstrual flow–PID(1)-Eighteen percent to 35% of all women with acute PID will develop chronic pelvic pain(1)–Previous cesarean section–Pelvic pathology-Interstitial cystitis (chronic bladder inflammation) (1)-Pelvic pain is reported in up to 70% of women with chronic interstitial cystitis-Endometriosis–Abuse (physical or sexual)-Approximately 40% to 50% of women with chronic pelvic pain have a history of physical or sexual abuse(1)–Psychological disorders-It is not clear whether mood disorder is a predisposing factor for, or a result of, chronic pelvic pain(9)–Mesh complications-Women with mesh implants with complications have a high degree of pain associated with worse quality of life (19)

Other reported risk factors–Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)(1)-The gastrointestinal system is the most common nongynecological contributor to chronic pelvic pain, typicallymanifesting as IBS(9)-About one third of women with chronic pelvic pain have IBS–Musculoskeletal disorders (e.g., increased lumbar lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis)(1)-Poor posture can result in chronically weak and deconditioned muscles, creating core and pelvic muscle imbalances,hypertonicity, and trigger points–Certain surgical procedures (e.g., cholecystectomy, groin hernia repair, pelvis fracture repair)(1)

overall contraindications precautions: In women with chronic pelvic pain presenting for physical therapy evaluation, confirm that the patient has undergone an exhaustive medical workup in an attempt to diagnosis the underlying cause of pain. If during the course of evaluation/ treatment the clinician suspects the cause of pain is nonmusculoskeletal in nature or there is coexisting serious pathology, the patient should be referred back to the treating physician
If an abusive situation is suspected, patient should be referred back to treating physician
Please see Clinical Review…Pelvic Girdle Pain: An Overview , referenced above, for more information on contraindications/ precautions in the case of acute pelvic pain
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Only clinicians specifically trained in the evaluation/treatment of the pelvic floor should carry out portions of the examination related to this region
Maneuvers that duplicate the patient’s pain should be noted, but undue reproduction of pain should be avoided to minimize guarding, which can interfere with performance of a thorough exam

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -Inquire about the history of the patient’s pain. When did the pain begin? Was there any specific event or trauma that the patient can recall? How often does the patient experience pain? Is the pain worsening or improving? Has the pain changed or spread over time? Are there any associated discomforts?

course of treatment.medical management: What diagnostic tests has the patient undergone? Any surgical procedures? Was a definitive diagnosis made? What were the reasons for physical therapy referral? Are there any specific orders/precautions/ contraindications noted?
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken as prescribed? Implantation of a levonorgestrel-releasing  intrauterine device(9) Long-term  use of NSAIDs or opioid narcotics is not recommended. Some patients may benefit from structured narcotic therapy; however, patients should be screened carefully for factors associated with high risk for misuse/ abuse(9) There are few controlled trials published specifically on the use of antidepressants or neuroleptics for the management of chronic pelvic pain. Current evidence supports tricyclic antidepressants as effective in treating chronic pain, including chronic pelvic pain. Neuroleptics are often prescribed when patients present with neuropathic symptoms(9) Combined oral contraceptives are effective in reducing pain associated with endometriosis(9)
diagnostic tests completed: Transvaginal ultrasound and MRI may be utilized to assist in diagnosis(20)
The interstitial cystitis symptom index may be implemented(21)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or complementary therapies (e.g., acupuncture, chiropractic care, dry needling) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. Surveys suggest that more than onethird of women with sexual pain never seek help from healthcare professionals, and 50% of women who do seek help are dissatisfied with their encounters(12)

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document any noted aggravating or easing factors (e.g., certain positions, following food consumption, voiding)(1) -Most women with chronic pelvic pain experience painful sexual activity(12)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Does the pain always occur in the same place?
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of pain symptoms (constant vs intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Ask the patient about other symptoms that present with the pain (e.g., vomiting, diaphoresis, constipation)(1)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables. Is it linked to the menstrual cycle?
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night related to the condition
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia) -In a chart review of 107 female patients with chronic pelvic pain, researchers in the United States found that psychological distress and impairment in daily activities were common, but that most areas of functional impairment were not associated with pain variables(13) -Rather, functional impairment was often related to higher levels of depression and anxiety -The authors suggest that the possibility that psychiatric symptoms contribute to the functional impairment in this population points to a need for a multidisciplinary approach in evaluation and treatment
history of present illness.respiratory status: Is there any reported respiratory compromise? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of same/similar diagnosis Has the patient ever been pregnant? If so, inquire about the course of the pregnancy and any complications during delivery Has the patient undergone any surgeries in the abdominal/pelvic region (which may be a factor in her chronic pelvic pain)? Any history of urinary or vaginal infections?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, gastrointestinal conditions, urinary system involvement, psychiatric conditions (e.g., depression, anxiety),(2)and orthopedic disorders Functional urinary problems (e.g., interstitial cystitis) and IBS are the most common medical conditions associated with chronic pelvic pain Psychological comorbidity, such as depression, and anxiety are more common in women with chronic pain(9)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports? Does the patient work? What are the physical demands of the work? Patients may find it difficult to sit for any length of time. They often sit on one buttock and have to frequently stand up, which makes travelling or working difficult
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Chronic pelvic pain is by definition sufficiently severe to interfere with ADLs. What impairments in ADLs does the patient report?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.) Evaluation procedures may include but are not limited to the following
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document patient’s height and weight and calculate BMI
relevant tests and measures.balance: Complete a general balance assessment. Assess single-leg stance for pain and instability with eyes open and closed
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Complete a gait assessment; note deviations (e.g., antalgic pattern, Trendelenburg gait) Joint integrity and mobility –Assess the bilateral hips for pain with provocation (e.g., Scour test) –Assess lumbar spine for joint mobility and pain –Motion tests, such as the trunk forward flexion test, are not reliable for assessing the SI joint(10)Assess for atypical muscle tone in the lower extremities Incoordination of the PFM and abdominal muscles may be observed. Note patient’s ability to relax muscles between contractions when instructed to contract and relax quickly and repeatedly
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Complete manual muscle testing of the trunk and bilateral lower extremities
observation inspection palpation includi: Palpate spinous processes, around/over SI joints, and region of trunk extensors for tenderness(1)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Complete a thorough postural assessment in standing, supine, and sitting. It is important to note that landmark testing to assess postural malalignments (e.g., elevated iliac crest height, posterior pelvic tilt) is not reliable for diagnosing dysfunction but can be utilized for general observation(1)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Complete a bilateral lower extremity and trunk active and passive ROM assessment –Document any compensations/abnormalities with active ROM trunk testing
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess deep tendon reflexes of the lower extremity Identify any impairment caused by chronic pelvic pain. Use of –Constipation Scoring System (CSS)(8) –Female Sexual Function Index (FSFI)(14) –Incontinence Impact Questionnaire(15)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: The clinician should assess for impaired sensation or hypersensitivities
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Perform SI provocation tests. If SI joint pain is reported on 3/5 of these tests, it is highly likely that SI joint dysfunction is present(10) -Gaenslen’s test -Patient is seated at the edge of the table and instructed to lie supine on the table. One knee is placed to the patient’s chest with the other leg straight. Therapist pushes down on the straight leg while pushing the knee of the other leg toward the chest -Sacral thrust test -Patient is prone; therapist directs a force through the patient’s joint on either side -Thigh thrust test -Patient is supine and one hip is flexed to 90°; therapist directs a force through the patient’s femur via the knee -Pelvic compression test -Patient is placed in side-lying  and therapist compresses the patient’s pelvis into the table by directing force through the iliac crest -FABER (flexed, abducted, externally rotated position of the extremity) test -Clinician directs force though knee and contralateral pelvis (over anterior superior iliac spine)A standardized questionnaire that may be administered to evaluate the severity of functional impairment as a result of pelvic girdle pain –Quality of life questionnaires –Pelvic Floor Distress Inventory (PFDI)(16) -Pelvic Floor Distress Inventory Short Form 20 (PFDI-20) –Pelvic Floor Impact Questionnaire (PFIQ)(16) -Pelvic Floor Impact Questionnaire Short Form 7 (PFIQ-7) –Pain Disability Index –Pelvic Organ Prolapse/Urinary Incontinence Sexual Function Questionnaire (PISQ-12)(17)

contraindications precautions: Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
other: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(4)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for treatment Access may be limited due to relatively few therapists with women’s health training. A listing of certified women’s health physical therapists can be found on the American Physical Therapy Association website at http:// www.womenshealthapta.org  (7) Awareness of women’s health therapy by the public and the healthcare community is somewhat limited, so there is often a significant delay between onset of symptoms and referral to physical therapy. Early referral to therapy is important for improving functional outcomes(7)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out There are numerous potential underlying causes of chronic pelvic pain that should be ruled out as part of the comprehensive evaluation and treatment program. Gastrointestinal dysfunction is often at the root of the pain.(1) For a more comprehensive list of possible causes of chronic pelvic pain, please see Causes , above
prognosis: One quarter of women with chronic pelvic pain can recover from the condition(5) –Based on a cohort study involving women with chronic pelvic pain –Sixty percent of women responded to the questionnaires –Seventy-two  women (> 18 years) participated in the study –Follow-up  – average of 3.4 years -Eighteen women declared they had experienced “recovery,” which was defined as pelvic pain for < 3 months/year -Eight (of the 18) women responded that they had no pain –The authors noted that there was no association detected between treatment (during the study period) and the outcomes of this cohort
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Refer patient to pain management specialist Sexual counseling, couples counseling, and psychotherapy can be helpful in the collaborative care of patients with chronic pelvic pain
other considerations: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and biofeedback therapy can be useful in reducing autonomic responses to painful stimuli(9)
treatment summary: European Association on Urology guidelines for chronic pelvic pain recommend that treating pelvic floor overactivity and myofascial trigger points should be considered in the management of chronic pelvic pain(6) –Pelvic floor muscle exercises should be applied as first-line treatment(6) -Relaxation and stretching should be included(6) –Biofeedback is recommended as therapy adjuvant to muscle exercises(6)

European Association on Urology guidelines on chronic pelvic pain recommend a holistic approach with biological, psychological, and social components(6) –Centers with a particular interest in pelvic pain that involve clinicians from several specialties, including those with expertise in chronic pain management, should be considered(6) . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program  Chronic pelvic pain Reduce/eliminate pain Patient education _ Patient should be taught various techniques to manage pain, including planning and pacing exercise and activities _ _ Prescription, application of devices and equipment _ Combination biofeedback and electrical stimulation units may also be employed _ _ (Please see Treatment summary , above)Progress each unique patient as appropriate and indicated _Verbal instruction/ education should be supported by written material in an effort to improve knowledge about the various components of chronic pelvic pain as well as

improvement in the various domains of fu: Pelvic Organ Prolapse/Urinary Incontinence Sexual Function Questionnaire (PISQ-12)

maintenance or prevention: The patient is advised to continue her prescribed home program and follow up with the appropriate healthcare professionals as indicated
patient education: See “Patient Information: Chronic Pelvic Pain in Women (Beyond the Basics),” http://www.uptodate.com/contents/chronic-pelvic-pain-in-women-beyond-the-basics

See “Chronic Pelvic Pain in Women” at the Mayo Clinic website, http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/chronic-pelvic-pain/home/ovc-20208133 Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
